title: Moulton Suffolk Walks

images.title: Ian Mitchell / Moulton Packhorse Bridge
images.caption: Moulton Packhorse Bridge. This bridge over the River Kennet was built in the 14th or 15th century alongside a ford on the packhorse route between Bury St Edmunds and Cambridge.

images.title: St Peter, Moulton by John Salmon, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: St Peter, Moulton. This fine church includes an early 14th-century tower topped by a gilded weather vane in the shape of a large pike by blacksmith. Restored in 1851, it is a grade I listed building

images.title: Parkland, Moulton by Hugh Venables, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Parkland, Moulton

images.title: Bob Jones / Dalham Hall
images.caption: Dalham Hall. The Hall, with its carefully manicured lawn, lies adjacent to St Mary's Church. While the manor of Dalham is first recorded as being owned by William the Sinner during the reign of Edward the Confessor, there is no evidence of a manor house on the site until much later.

images.title: Footpath alongside the River Kennett by Rob Noble, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Footpath alongside the River Kennett

images.title: Stile and footpath to Gazeley by Rob Noble, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Stile and footpath to Gazeley

description: This attractive Suffolk based village includes several picturesque thatched cottages, views of the River Kennett and a noteworthy medieval Packhorse Bridge. It is located in a lovely rural spot just a few miles east of Newmarket. This circular walk from the village makes use of a section of the Icknield Way Path to explore the countryside to the east of the settlement. The walk starts from the ancient Pack Horse Bridge on the eastern side of the village. You then follow the waymarked path east to visit the neighbouring village of Gazeley. The route then heads through Brick Kiln Wood, passing Dalham Hall and the small settlement of Dalham. The final section takes you north past Hawson Hills and Catford Bridge before returning to the village.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: On the village green there's the Packhorse Inn for post exercise refreshment. They serve high quality food and also provide rooms if you'd like to stay in the area. The inn is located near the old bridge on Bridge Street at postcode CB8 8SP.

display_address: Brookside, West Suffolk, Suffolk, England, CB8 8SG, United Kingdom
